name: NPR
text:
1 in 5 Americans struggles with medical bills.

Here are 7 things you can do to get medical debt reduced — or even forgiven, from @NPRLifeKit:
https://t.co/K5Z3FBzuyE

name: NPR
text: Japanese officials are criticizing the U.S. military's measures to prevent infections after a new outbreak of COVID-19 cases among American service members stationed on Okinawa. https://t.co/u9br6LfjER

name: NPR
text:
The Ventura County Medical Examiner's Office has ruled the death of actress Naya Rivera to be an accidental drowning. 
https://t.co/P6R9sixpuu

name: NPR
text:
Over the last three months, Delta Air Lines lost nearly $6 billion — and now a slow, brief recovery in air travel has stalled amid a big resurgence in coronavirus infections. 
https://t.co/18FAOYtr3X

name: NPR
text:
Pamela Talkin, the first female Supreme Court marshal, has retired after 19 years at the nation's high court. Also retiring is Christine Luchok Fallon, the first woman to hold the job of reporter of decisions.
https://t.co/tlabkzApOO

name: NPR
text:
Adm. Brett Giroir, who oversees the federal testing response, tells NPR that the U.S. is "going to expand testing probably two or threefold within the next couple of months."
https://t.co/TjKSVklToY

name: NPR
text:
The U.K. will ban equipment from Chinese tech company Huawei in its 5G network. 

The decision follows sustained pressure from the U.S., including threats to withhold intelligence from allies that use Huawei products.
https://t.co/h37FWTCQN8

name: NPR
text:
There's a massive glut of oil on the market due to the global economic slowdown.

People who've never considered storing oil are now coming up with creative ways to take advantage of an unusual opportunity.
https://t.co/NGqAvFGPQs

name: NPR
text:
President Trump dismissed a question about why police have killed so many Black people, saying "so are white people!"

Data show that while more white people overall may be killed by police annually, Black Americans are killed at a far higher rate.
https://t.co/m5em3Psz11

name: NPR
text: Nearly 100 years later, officials are digging for the mass graves from the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, in which as many as 300 African American residents were slaughtered by white mobs. https://t.co/lVOAuAWJCq

name: NPR
text: "Excited delirium" long has been a part of police training in parts of the U.S. The agitated condition, said to be caused by drugs or mental illness, could play a role in the case of George Floyd's killing. But one doctor calls it "a wastebasket term." https://t.co/A7tdFaCcUL

name: NPR
text: Fans, graphic designers and members of the public have been proposing alternative names and logos for Washington's NFL team for years. Check out some of their ideas. @wamu885 https://t.co/aGNSR6XsDn

name: NPR
text:
Jena Martinez-Inzunza was one of three teachers in a rural Arizona school district who contracted COVID-19 while working in a classroom together.

One of her colleagues died.

"It's just going to be worse when we repopulate schools" this fall, she says.
https://t.co/GiKjUnvXpm

name: NPR
text: Sen. Tammy Duckworth said Tuesday that she would lift a hold on more than 1,100 senior military promotions, after the Defense Department assured her it didn't block the promotion of Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman. https://t.co/c5gaj9iEmo

name: NPR
text:
President Trump is making major changes to a bedrock environmental law, aiming to speed up approval for projects like pipelines.

Critics say the move could discount those projects' impact on climate change — and sideline the concerns of poor communities.
https://t.co/5ELgL3XxRG

name: NPR
text:
Attorneys representing the family of George Floyd are preparing a civil lawsuit against "the City of Minneapolis and police officers."
https://t.co/GL0iwsHyPI

name: NPR
text:
A federal appellate court has temporarily blocked a lower-court order to shut down and empty the Dakota Access Pipeline. The operator, Energy Transfer, can continue pumping while the case is pending.
https://t.co/B8TaeFpiW0

name: NPR
text:
Despite being classified by the World Bank as low-income, Rwanda has vowed to identify every coronavirus case.

Anyone who tests positive is immediately quarantined at a dedicated COVID-19 clinic. And all testing and treatment is provided for free.
https://t.co/kuPBwJMruS

name: NPR
text:
RT @hansilowang: SCOOP: @NPR has now confirmed 4 states (Iowa, South Carolina, South Dakota, Nebraska) have agreed to share their state driver's license & state ID info to help Trump admin efforts to figure out the US citizenship status of every adult living in the country
https://t.co/wCYiuVFhDM

name: NPR
text:
In Washington, D.C., the coronavirus has killed Black residents at 5.9 times the rate of white residents.

An investigation finds that Mayor Muriel Bowser's administration made crucial missteps in the early days of the pandemic.
https://t.co/Jcsy5MQbcn

name: NPR
text:
Four states — Iowa, Nebraska, South Carolina and South Dakota — have agreed to share their driver's license and state ID records to help the Trump administration figure out the U.S. citizenship status of every adult living in the country, NPR has learned.
https://t.co/l6WTKbF9lj

name: NPR
text:
Air Force combat veteran MJ Hegar won her Democratic primary in Texas and will now face GOP incumbent Sen. John Cornyn.

In Maine, state Democratic Speaker of the House Sara Gideon will challenge Republican Sen. Susan Collins.
https://t.co/ZvkRJomVNC

name: NPR
text:
Congressional investigators are looking into some companies that received multi-million-dollar government contracts related to COVID-19, saying the companies lacked experience — and, in some cases, had political connections to the Trump administration.
https://t.co/QCaQV6Zlys

name: NPR
text: RT @rachelnpr: Just got done talking with Mary Trump . Click to hear the news out of our conversation. https://t.co/WQNBkHazaC

name: NPR
text:
People were advised to postpone hiking the Appalachian Trail during the pandemic, over concerns about hygiene and the possibility of hikers spreading the virus to rural towns.

But some hikers decided to stay the course.
https://t.co/3pIZb2dV3W

name: NPR
text:
The National Academy of Sciences has issued 9 recommendations for reopening schools — including collaborating with public health authorities and, when possible, prioritizing full-time, in-person classes for grades K-5 and for students with special needs.
https://t.co/ryxN8RAAVu

name: NPR
text:
Senior Trump adviser Peter Navarro, who has no medical training, has been publicly criticizing Dr. Anthony Fauci.

The White House has struggled to explain why top aides appear to be at open war with the U.S. government's top infectious disease expert.
https://t.co/NmxMr5g8nZ

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRItsBeenAMin: .@SorayaMcDonald has been thinking a lot about race and the news. So @samsanders asked her, as a Black journalist, what change does she want to see?

✅ Structural change within newsroom leadership
✅ Meaningful and honest news coverage of race

🔊 https://t.co/GSIZuerIfI https://t.co/GJ5ria3DSe

name: NPR
text:
Republican Sen. Kelly Loeffler, who co-owns the WNBA’s Atlanta Dream, is calling on the league to drop support of the Black Lives Matter movement.

“We need less  — not more politics in sports," she says.  The team's players strongly disagree.
https://t.co/UstOnEAI2B
